Also POV etc.|date=September 2017}} {{Feminism sidebar}} '''White feminism''' is a form of [[feminism]] that focuses on the struggles of white women while failing to address distinct forms of [[oppression]] faced by [[ethnic minority]] women and women lacking other [[Privilege (social inequality)|privileges]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frankenberg|first=Ruth|date=1993-01-01|title=Growing up White: Feminism, Racism and the Social Geography of Childhood|journal=Feminist Review|issue=45|pages=51–84|doi=10.2307/1395347|jstor=1395347}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=ABPP|first=Monnica T. Williams, Ph D.|date=2019-01-16|title=How White Feminists Oppress Black Women: When Feminism Functions as White Supremacy|url=https://chacruna.net/how-white-feminists-oppress-black-women-when-feminism-functions-as-white-supremacy/|access-date=2020-10-13|website=Chacruna|language=en-US}}</ref> White feminism is criticized for its feminist theories that focus solely on the experience of white women and fail to acknowledge and integrate the notion of [[intersectionality]] in the struggle for equality.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Coaston |first1=Jane |title=The Intersectionality Wars |url=http://www.vox.com/the-highlight/2019/5/20/18542843/intersectionality-conservatism-law-race-gender-discrimination. |website=www.vox.com |accessdate=24 August 2020}}</ref> This approach was predominantly visible in the first waves of feminism which generally centered around the empowerment of white middle-class females in Western societies.<ref>{{cite book |last1=De Beauvoir |first1=Simone |title=The Second Sex |date=2015 |publisher=Vintage Digital}}</ref>
While the term ''white feminism'' and debate around the topic are relatively recent, its critics date back to the beginning of the feminist movement, especially in the United States.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Staples |first1=Brent |title=When the Suffrage Movement Sold Out to White Supremacy |journal=New York Times |date=2 February 2019 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/02/opinion/sunday/women-voting-19th-amendment-white-supremacy.html. |accessdate=24 August 2020}}</ref> By theorizing the overlapping systems of oppression in society (dependent on race, ethnicity, sexuality, gender, etc.), the development of Crenshaw's theory of intersectionality has recently galvanized critics of white feminism, described as restrictive and discriminatory.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Crenshaw |first1=Kimberlée |title=On Intersectionality the Essential Writings of Kimberle Crenshaw |date=2018 |publisher=New Press}}</ref>
== Origins == Since its origin, feminism in Western societies has been represented by white educated women primarily focusing on the right to political representation and vote.<ref>{{Cite web|last=ABPP|first=Monnica T. Williams, Ph D.|date=2019-01-16|title=How White Feminists Oppress Black Women: When Feminism Functions as White Supremacy|url=https://chacruna.net/how-white-feminists-oppress-black-women-when-feminism-functions-as-white-supremacy/|access-date=2020-11-12|website=Chacruna|language=en-US}}</ref> One of the most prominent examples of the early feminist revindications is found in Mary Wollstonecraft's text, ''[[A Vindication of the Rights of Woman]]'' published in 1792 and in which she advocates for moral and political equality between men and women.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wollstonecraft |first1=Mary |title=Mary Wollstonecraft, A Vindication of the Rights of Woman |url=http://www.bl.uk/collection-items/mary-wollstonecraft-a-vindication-of-the-rights-of-woman. |website=The British Library |accessdate=24 August 2020}}</ref> Similarly, in France, Olympe de Gouges advocated for women’s rights in her [[Declaration of the Rights of Woman and of the Female Citizen]] as early as 1791.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Declaration of the Rights of Woman and of the [Female] Citizen {{!}} Definition & Facts|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/Declaration-of-the-Rights-of-Woman-and-of-the-Female-Citizen|access-date=2020-11-12|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|language=en}}</ref>
== In first-wave feminism == [[File:Feminist Suffrage Parade in New York City, 1912.jpeg|thumb|[[Women's suffrage]] parade in New York City, May 6, 1912.]] [[First-wave feminism]] began in the [[early modern period]] and continued into the early 20th century, and focused primarily on legal issues pertaining to women, especially [[women's suffrage]]. This wave officially started with the 1848 [[Seneca Falls Convention]] in Seneca Falls, New York, towards the end of the [[Industrial Revolution]]. The goal of this wave was to open up opportunities for women, with a focus on suffrage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pacificu.edu/about-us/news-events/four-waves-feminism|title=Four Waves of Feminism {{!}} Pacific University|website=www.pacificu.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-11-20}}</ref> It was a movement predominantly organized and defined by middle-class, educated white women, and concentrated mostly on issues pertaining to them.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://kids.britannica.com/women/article-216012|title=Encyclopædia Britannica's Guide to Women's History|website=kids.britannica.com|access-date=2016-12-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iep.utm.edu/fem-race/|title=Feminism and Race in the United States|last=Elkholy|first=Sharin N.|date=|website=Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy|publisher=|access-date=27 December 2016}}</ref>
Some ethnic minority women were embraced in the movement, such as suffragette Princess [[Sophia Duleep Singh]] among the British first-wave feminists. However, there is little evidence that black women participated in the [[Women's suffrage in the United Kingdom|British suffragette]] effort. In 1893, [[New Zealand]] became the first nation to grant women of all races the right to vote; this was met with anger from suffragists including [[Millicent Fawcett]], who expressed displeasure that [[Māori people|Māori women]] in one of the British colonies were able to vote, while British women of society were not.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/womens-life/11914757/Racism-and-the-suffragettes-the-uncomfortable-truth.html|title=The uncomfortable truth about racism and the suffragettes|last=Sanghani|first=Radhika|date=6 October 2015|work=|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|access-date=27 December 2016|via=}}</ref> [[Susan B. Anthony]] (a staunch [[Abolitionism|abolitionist]]) and [[Elizabeth Cady Stanton]] fought for white women to get the right to vote in the [[United States|United States of America]], prioritizing this above black men getting the right to vote.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theroot.com/articles/culture/2016/04/black-feminism-white-feminism/|title='When and Where I Enter': The Racist Expectations of Whites-Only Feminism|last=Savali|first=Kirsten West|date=23 April 2016|work=|newspaper=The Root|language=en-US|access-date=27 December 2016|via=}}</ref> Anthony and Stanton were wary of creating an "aristocracy of sex"; rather, they proposed universal suffrage, such that the black community and women (including black women) get enfranchised at the same time.
Nevertheless, their “[[History of Woman Suffrage]]”, is a clear example of white feminism as it widely disregards the role of black women while focusing on white figures of the movement. While 1920 is celebrated as the abstention of Women’s suffrage in the United States, African American women were still evicted from voting polls in the Jim Crow South. At that time, white women largely viewed African American women as excluded from the feminist movement and the black suffragist Mary Church Terrel was denied the help of white activists.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Staples |first1=Brent |title=When the Suffrage Movement Sold Out to White Supremacy |date=2 February 2019 |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/02/opinion/sunday/women-voting-19th-amendment-white-supremacy.html.}}</ref> Still, African American women have had an important role in the battle for equality in the United States. As early as 1851, [[Sojourner Truth]], a former slave, delivered a speech “Ain’t I a woman” in which she calls for what would be later on described as intersectionality.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Gender and the Law Blog: Soujourner Truth's Ain't I a Woman Speech and Intersectional Feminism|url=https://lawprofessors.typepad.com/gender_law/2019/02/soujourner-truths-aint-i-a-woman-speech.html|access-date=2020-11-12|website=lawprofessors.typepad.com|language=en}}</ref>
== In second-wave feminism == Second wave feminism began in the 1960s and lasted through the 1980s. This time period focused on women in the work environment, sexuality, reproductive rights, domestic violence and rape.<ref>{{Citation|title=Second-wave feminism|date=2020-10-20|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Second-wave_feminism&oldid=984463630|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2020-11-12}}</ref> [[Second-wave feminism]], particularly at its outset, was similarly shaped by middle-class, educated white women, and again it did not tend to consider issues that were specifically relevant to ethnic minority women.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.progressivewomensleadership.com/a-brief-history-the-three-waves-of-feminism/|title=A Brief History: The Three Waves of Feminism|date=2015-09-22|work=Progressive Women's Leadership|access-date=2017-11-20|language=en-US}}</ref> During this time, the Miss America Pageant took place in Atlantic City in 1968. Feminists gathered outside, throwing bras, gridles and fake eyelashes into a trash can to demonstrate their frustrations with the male gaze and the degrading beauty standards that surrounded the Miss America Pageant. <ref>{{Cite web|title=Download Limit Exceeded|url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/messages/downloadsexceeded.html|access-date=2020-11-12|website=citeseerx.ist.psu.edu}}</ref> The second wave also began to incorporate women of color, whereas the first wave focused mostly on white, cis-gender, middle class women. <ref>{{Cite web|date=2015-10-25|title=Four Waves of Feminism|url=https://www.pacificu.edu/magazine/four-waves-feminism|access-date=2020-11-12|website=Pacific University|language=en}}</ref>
The Second Sex by Simone de Beauvoir, stands as the one of the most striking example of the essentialization of women in the figure of the white bourgeoise mother and hence disregard for other forms of oppressions such as race or sexuality. Nevertheless, this book has appeared as a landmark which has enabled other more complex theories to emerge.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Garcia |first1=Manon |title=On Ne Naît Pas Soumise, on Le Devient |date=2019 |publisher=Climats}}</ref>
During the second and third-wave feminist periods, scholars from [[marginalised]] communities began to write back against the way in which feminist movements had been [[Essentialism|essentializing]] the experiences of women. The notable feminist scholar [[bell hooks]] brought this issue to the forefront of feminist thought, regularly writing about the struggles that black women experienced and emphasizing that the feminist movement was exclusionary towards those women by virtue of its inattention to the interactions between [[race (human categorization)|race]], gender, and class.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Feminism and 'Race'|last=hooks|first=bell|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2001|isbn=978-0-19-878236-0|editor-last=Bhavnani|editor-first=Kum-Kum|location=New York|pages=33–39|chapter=Black Women: Shaping Feminist Theory|quote=|via=}}</ref> hooks argued that white women should recognise the fact that they, like ethnic minority men, occupied a position of being both oppressed while also being oppressors. In an attempt to shun the critics addressed by scholars from minorities exposing second-wave feminism, the latter sought to divert attention by exposing inequalities and injustice faced by women abroad. This has been criticized by many scholars which have labeled it under several names such as missionary or imperialist feminism.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Maira |first1=Susaina |title="Good" and "Bad Muslim Citizens: Feminists, Terrorists, and U. S. Orientalisms" |date=2009 |publisher=Feminist Studies |pages=631–656}}</ref>
== In third-wave feminism == Led by Gen X, third wave feminism began in the 1990s when issues surrounding sexuality and pornography were brought to the forefront.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title=Feminism - The third wave of feminism|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/feminism|access-date=2020-11-12|website=Encyclopedia Britannica|language=en}}</ref> Third wave feminists coined the term "riot grrls" which represented strong, independent and passionate feminists in this time period. "Grrls" were typuically described as angry feminists fighting against sexism. <ref>{{Cite web|title=Riot Grrrls, Action Girl, Third Wave movement {{!}} Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies|url=http://www.gsws.pitt.edu/blogs/alm206/riot-grrrls-action-girl-third-wave-movement|access-date=2020-11-12|website=www.gsws.pitt.edu}}</ref> The third wave was inspired by the post-modern society and worked to reclaim derogatory words used to shame women like, 'slut,' 'whore,' and 'slut' and take away the power these words gave men over women. This also worked to advocate for women's sexual liberation and expression of gender identity. <ref name=":3" />This wave also included even more women of color and women from different classes than previous waves.<ref name=":3" />
== 21st century intersectional feminism, or fourth wave == During [[Third-wave feminism|third wave feminism]] and at the start of fourth wave feminism after 2010, feminists sometimes emphasize intersectional perspectives in their work.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2016/entries/feminist-power|title=Feminist Perspectives on Power|last=Allen|first=Amy|date=Fall 2016|website=Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|publisher=The Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=February 3, 2017}}</ref> Despite this, some have argued that feminist media continues to overrepresent the struggles of straight, middle class, white women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nadeau|first=Mary-Jo|year=2009|title=Troubling Herstory: Unsettling White Multiculturalism in Canadian Feminism|journal=Canadian Woman Studies|volume=27|pages=6–13|id={{ProQuest|217441442}}}}</ref><ref name=":2" /> The position held by some modern feminist authors that [[racism]] is not an element of society that feminism needs to be concerned with has also been cited as exemplifying white feminism.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://everydayfeminism.com/2015/09/white-feminists-anti-racism/|title=When White Feminists Respond to Anti-Racism Like Men Respond to Feminism — Everyday Feminism|website=everydayfeminism.com|access-date=2016-12-07}}</ref> Nevertheless, in recent years, authors like Kimberle [[Kimberlé Williams Crenshaw|Crenshaw]] have developed the theory of intersectionality, a clear opposition to white feminism. Rather than analyzing society from a unique perspective of race or gender, she calls for a more complex analysis of systems of oppression using multiple and overlapping lenses such as race, gender, sexuality, etc.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Crenshaw |first1=Kimberlé |title=On intersectionality the essential writings of Kimberle Crenshaw |date=2018 |publisher=New Press |location=New York}}</ref>
White feminism portrays a view of feminism that can be separated from issues of class, race, ability, and other oppressions. An example of white feminism in the present day can be seen in the work of Emily Shire,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bustle.com/authors/1559-emily-shire|title=Emily Shire|website=www.bustle.com|access-date=2017-03-08}}</ref> politics editor at Bustle and an op-ed contributor for [[The New York Times]]. Shire argues that feminism excludes some women who do not share political viewpoints when it takes positions on Israel and Palestine, efforts to raise the minimum wage, and efforts to block the construction of oil pipelines.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/07/opinion/does-feminism-have-room-for-zionists.html|title=Does Feminism Have Room for Zionists?|last=Shire|first=Emily|date=2017-03-07|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-08|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Shire's position contrasts with intersectional feminist activists who view pay equity, social justice, and international human rights as essential and inseparable commitments of feminism, as articulated in the [[Day Without a Woman]] platform that "[recognizes] the enormous value that women of all backgrounds add to our socio-economic system – while receiving lower wages and experiencing greater inequities, vulnerability to discrimination, sexual harassment, and job insecurity".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.womensmarch.com/womensday/|title=A Day Without a Woman|website=Women's March on Washington|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-08}}</ref> While Shire advocates for a feminism that achieves inclusivity by avoiding political positions so as to not alienate women who disagree with those positions,<ref name=":1" /> organizers of the Women's March hold the principle that "women have intersecting identities" necessitating a movement that focuses on a "comprehensive agenda".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://static1.squarespace.com/static/584086c7be6594762f5ec56e/t/587ffb20579fb3554668c111/1484782369253/WMW+Guiding+Vision+%26+Definition+of+Principles.pdf|title=Guiding Vision and Definition of Principles|last=Women's March|date=March 8, 2017|website=www.womensmarch.com|access-date=March 8, 2017}}</ref>
It has also been argued that the beliefs of some feminists that [[hijab]]s, [[burqa]]s, and [[Niqāb|niqabs]] are oppressive towards [[Muslim]] women are representative of white feminism. Many [[Women in Islam|Muslim women]] have spoken out in defense of their religious dress practices.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://this.org/2015/03/11/the-trouble-with-white-feminism/|title=THIS → The trouble with (white) feminism|website=this.org|access-date=2016-12-08}}</ref> One example of this belief is the [[Islamic scarf controversy in France]] that has argued against the Islamic veil by many French feminists claiming that Islam threatens women's autonomy and thus choosing to wear one is meaningless, when many Muslim women say that it is a choice and that denying the choice only restricts a woman's freedom. They say that some wear it as a personal commitment; others reject the notion that the veil is a religious sign.<ref>{{cite book |last1=R. Bowen |first1=John |authorlink1=Women's autonomy, Islam, and the French State. |editor1-last=B. Brettell |editor1-first=Caroline |editor2-last=F. Sargent |editor2-first=Carolyn |title=Gender in Cross-Cultural Perspective |date=2017 |publisher=Routledge |location=London; New York |isbn=978-1-138-21664-8 |pages=371-380 |accessdate=8 October 2020 |chapter=26}}</ref> Some Muslim women see burqa as freeing, because it enabled them to be in the public sphere while still observing moral and religious requirements.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Abu-Lughod|first=Lila|date=|title=The Muslim Woman: The Power of Images and the Danger of Pity|work=|url=|url-status=live|access-date=}}</ref>
[[Trans-exclusionary radical feminism]] has also been a topic of discussion. Feminism requires fighting for women's rights, but trans-exclusionary radical feminists do not see [[trans women]] as women. Many of them argue against trans women changing their sex on legal documents, say that ''lesbian'' as an identity is disappearing, that trans men are not men, and that gay children need protection when they think they are transgender.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Lewis|first=Sophie|date=2019-02-07|title=Opinion {{!}} How British Feminism Became Anti-Trans (Published 2019)|language=en-US|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/07/opinion/terf-trans-women-britain.html|access-date=2020-10-08|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Critics, especially within the [[LGBT]] community, have expressed their discontent with these arguments. They feel that privileged white women who make these arguments will make trans women, especially trans women of color, more at risk for discrimination and that they fail to consider many other factors that trans women have to deal with.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tudor |first1=Alyosxa |title=Terfism is White Distraction: On BLM, Decolonising the Curriculum, Anti-Gender Attacks and Feminist Transphobia |url=https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/gender/2020/06/19/terfism-is-white-distraction-on-blm-decolonising-the-curriculum-anti-gender-attacks-and-feminist-transphobia/ |website=Engenderings |accessdate=8 October 2020}}</ref>
